Data Wrangling

Author

Kasper Valtonen

Challenge:

# Setting up libraries
library(vroom)
library(tidyverse)
#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──

Let’s import the reduced data to R with vroom

#Importing data
col_types <- list(
  patent_id = col_character(),
  id = col_character(),
  assignee_id = col_character(),
  type = col_integer(),
  date = col_date("%Y-%m-%d"),
  num_claims = col_integer(),
  organization = col_character(),
  mainclass_id = col_character(),
  sequence = col_integer()
)

patent_tbl <- vroom(
            file       = "C:\\Users\\35844\\ML\\ss23-bdsb-TurvaKassu\\Patent_data_reduced\\patent.tsv", 
            delim      = "\t", 
            col_types  = col_types,
            na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
        )
#> Warning: The following named parsers don't match the column names: patent_id,
#> assignee_id, type, organization, mainclass_id, sequence
patent_assignee_tbl <- vroom(
            file = "C:\\Users\\35844\\ML\\ss23-bdsb-TurvaKassu\\Patent_data_reduced\\patent_assignee.tsv",
            delim      = "\t", 
            col_types  = col_types,
            na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
            )
#> Warning: The following named parsers don't match the column names: id, type,
#> date, num_claims, organization, mainclass_id, sequence
assignee_tbl <- vroom(
            file = "C:\\Users\\35844\\ML\\ss23-bdsb-TurvaKassu\\Patent_data_reduced\\assignee.tsv",
            delim      = "\t", 
            col_types  = col_types,
            na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
            )
#> Warning: The following named parsers don't match the column names: patent_id,
#> assignee_id, date, num_claims, mainclass_id, sequence
uspc_tbl <- vroom(
            file = "C:\\Users\\35844\\ML\\ss23-bdsb-TurvaKassu\\Patent_data_reduced\\uspc.tsv",
            delim      = "\t", 
            col_types  = col_types,
            na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
            )
#> Warning: The following named parsers don't match the column names: id,
#> assignee_id, type, date, num_claims, organization
# Combine tibbles
complete_patent_tbl <- left_join(
  patent_tbl, patent_assignee_tbl, by = c("id" = "patent_id")) %>%
  left_join(assignee_tbl, by = c("assignee_id" = "id")) %>%
  left_join(uspc_tbl, by = c("id" = "patent_id"))
#> Warning in left_join(., uspc_tbl, by = c(id = "patent_id")): Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`.
#> ℹ Row 2 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`.
#> ℹ Row 109363 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`.
#> ℹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship =
#>   "many-to-many"` to silence this warning.

Transform tibble into data.table and excluding NA values for organization

patent_dt <- as.data.table(complete_patent_tbl)[!is.na(organization)][!is.na(mainclass_id)]

Question 1: Which organizations posses most number of patents?

number_of_patents <- patent_dt[, .N, by=organization] %>%
  .[order(-N)] %>%
  .[1:10]
print(number_of_patents)
#>                                    organization     N
#>  1: International Business Machines Corporation 19056
#>  2:               Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. 14523
#>  3:                      Canon Kabushiki Kaisha  9467
#>  4:                            Sony Corporation  8372
#>  5:                       QUALCOMM Incorporated  7322
#>  6:                       Microsoft Corporation  7195
#>  7:                    Kabushiki Kaisha Toshiba  6957
#>  8:                                 Google Inc.  6082
#>  9:                         LG Electronics Inc.  5694
#> 10:                       Panasonic Corporation  5641

Question 2: Companies with most patents in August 2014.

First we need to add date column to previous dt manipulation

number_of_patents_august <- patent_dt[year(date) == 2014 & month(date) == 8, .N, by=organization] %>%
  .[order(-N)] %>%
  .[1:10]
print(number_of_patents)
#>                                    organization     N
#>  1: International Business Machines Corporation 19056
#>  2:               Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. 14523
#>  3:                      Canon Kabushiki Kaisha  9467
#>  4:                            Sony Corporation  8372
#>  5:                       QUALCOMM Incorporated  7322
#>  6:                       Microsoft Corporation  7195
#>  7:                    Kabushiki Kaisha Toshiba  6957
#>  8:                                 Google Inc.  6082
#>  9:                         LG Electronics Inc.  5694
#> 10:                       Panasonic Corporation  5641

Question 3: What is the most innovative tech industry?

Solve the main class of most number of patents

# Get the top10 orgs with most patents
top10_orgs <- patent_dt[, .N, by=organization] %>%
  .[order(-N)] %>%
  .[1:10] %>%
  select(organization)

# Only include rows with orgs from top10_orgs and group by mainclass_id
top5_mainclasses <- patent_dt[organization %in% top10_orgs$organization, 
                              .N, by=mainclass_id] %>%
                    .[order(-N)] %>%
                    .[1:5]

print(top5_mainclasses)
#>    mainclass_id    N
#> 1:          257 7979
#> 2:          455 6191
#> 3:          370 5483
#> 4:          348 4113
#> 5:          709 4018
